body_content.explanation: to cut or damage a surface or your skin slightly with or on something sharp or rough:
examples: We scratched the wall trying to get the bed into Martha's room.
Be careful not to scratch yourself on the roses.
A few chickens were scratching about/around (= searching with their beaks) in the yard for grain.

body_content.explanation: If you scratch something on or off a surface, you add it or remove it by scratching:
examples: People have been scratching their names on this rock for years.
I scratched some paint off the door as I was getting out of the car.

body_content.explanation: If an animal scratches, it rubs something with its claws (= sharp nails):
examples: The dog's scratching at the door – he wants to be let in.

body_content.explanation: to rub your skin with your nails:
examples: He was scratching (at) his mosquito bites.
Hannah scratched her head thoughtfully.

body_content.explanation: to remove yourself or another person or an animal from a competition before the start:
examples: The world champion scratched from the 800 metres after injuring herself the day before.
They scratched the horse from the race because she had become lame.

body_content.explanation: to decide not to do something you had planned to do:
examples: We had to scratch our plans when I lost my job.

body_content.explanation: used for saying you take back something you have just said, especially in order to say it in a better way or to say something different:
examples: Everything I did was in the cause of safety. No, scratch that – not safety but survival.
It would have been better to say your brother wasn’t driving the car at all. Scratch that – telling the truth is usually best in the end.
Her legs were covered in scratches and bruises after her walk through the forest.
There was a scratch on the CD.
Amazingly, he survived the accident without a scratch (= without suffering any injuries at all).
That dog is having a good scratch. It must have fleas.

body_content.explanation: a person or animal that leaves a competition before it starts:
examples: The Australian Open winner was a late scratch.
He was a last-minute scratch from Sunday's game because of inflammation in his right knee.

body_content.explanation: a group of people brought together in a hurry in order to play together on a particular occasion:
examples: He knew that any shortcomings of what was essentially a scratch side would be exposed by the opposition.
